awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: IA: Big Data Analytics for Optimized Planning of Smart, Sustainable, and Connected Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Transforming villages, towns, and cities into smart, connected, and sustainable communities is one of the most critical technological challenges of the coming decade. Realizing this vision is contingent upon enabling existing community infrastructure such as transportation, communications, and energy systems, to seamlessly integrate sustainable components such as renewable sources, smart sensors, and electric vehicles. Such an integration will ensure that tomorrow's communities are truly sustainable and connected by exhibiting desirable qualities that include: a) zero energy, in that they are self-sufficient in their energy production, b) zero outage, in that communication links across the community are ultra-reliable and experience significantly low interruption, and c) zero congestion, in that the traffic congestion is minimized across the community. With this overarching vision, the goal of this project is to develop a new planning framework for smart, connected and sustainable communities that allows meeting such zero-energy, zero-outage, and zero-congestions goals by optimally deciding on how, when, and where to deploy or upgrade a community's infrastructure. These decisions will be driven by massive volumes of community data, stemming from multiple sources that can include mobility, energy, traffic, communication demands, and other socio-technological information, to make informed decisions on how to gradually and organically transform a community into a fully sustainable and truly connected environment.  The scale and heterogeneity of this problem necessitates the need for innovation in the tools used to process, analyze, and visualize heterogeneous data, as well as the data-aware metrics used to monitor the performance of this community infrastructure. One key element of this research is creation of a virtual testbed that can accurately reconstruct, simulate, and evaluate the theoretical framework by leveraging real-world big data sets from Virginia Tech and a zero-energy community in Florida as well as other sources, such as the DOE.   The testbed is intended to be open access and will be able to support both research at host institution as well as other users requiring non-proprietary multi-domain open-data sets.  The holistic nature of this research is thus expected to catalyze the global deployment of sustainable and connected communities. The proposed research will be complemented by a smart community big data challenge event that will enable broad community participation. The educational plan includes new big data-centric courses, as well as a large-scale involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in big data and smart communities research. Broad dissemination is ensured via open-source software and periodic workshops and tutorials. K-12 outreach events will be organized to attract under-represented student groups to big data research.

This transformative research will lay the theoretical and practical foundations of smart, connected, and sustainable communities by developing the first big data-driven holistic approach to joint planning, optimization, and deployment of community infrastructure for systems of critical importance, such as communication, energy, and transportation networks. By bringing together interdisciplinary domain experts from data science, electrical engineering, and civil and architectural engineering, this research will yield several innovations: 1) Novel big data techniques for faithfully creating spatio-temporal models for smart communities that integrate data from heterogeneous sources and shed light on the composition and operation of a given smart community, 2) Novel, data-driven performance metrics that advance powerful mathematical tools from stochastic geometry to explicitly quantify the health of smart communities via tractable notions of zero energy, zero outage, and zero congestion, 3) Advanced analytical tools that bring forward novel ideas from optimization theory to devise the most effective strategies for deploying, upgrading, and operating various community infrastructure nodes, given the scale, dynamics, and structure of both the data and the community, and 4) A virtual smart community testbed that can accurately reconstruct, simulate, and evaluate the theoretical framework by leveraging open non-proprietary real-world big data sets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global climate change and resulting frequent extreme weather events have highlighted the significance of energy sustainability and resilience. Infrastructure in future smart and connected communities (SCC) is envisioned as an aggregate of public services, including energy, transportation, and communication systems, all intertwined with each other. The intrinsic interdependency among these systems may exert the underlying influence on both design and operation of these heterogeneous infrastructures. Impacts to one system potentially creates a cascading effect that compromises the systems’ operations. Furthermore, increased electrification and connectivity will further complicate these interconnections. Thus, codesign and co-operational enhancements are necessary in order to fasten the transition towards smart, sustainable, resilient, net-zero energy and low carbon economies.  Evaluating such complex system interactions in both futuristic and present communities require highly sophisticated and computationally intensive modeling and simulation tools.

In response to these preeminent challenges, this research proposes a flexible, open-source, integrated modeling framework suitable for modeling complex infrastructure systems. 

To model futuristic smart community a novel multi-level, multi-layer, multi-agent approach is proposed to enable flexible modeling of the interconnected systems. We have implemented the framework and the underlying models in Modelica, an equation-based object-oriented modeling language. Component and system-level models are developed of each infrastructure systems namely 1) Energy systems (power grid, electrical distribution network, building electrical loads, distributed energy generation, energy storage); 2) Transportation (roads, EV charging stations, velocity on roads and travel time); 3) Communication (communication towers, signal transmission delay); 4) Water distribution (pumping station, booster pumps, storage tank, hydraulic pipe network); with added layer of physical, cyber, and logical interdependencies between systems. We have evaluated the community operations and interdependencies through various case studies by gradually increasing complexity of the models from two to four coupled systems.

Modeling exiting communities require a different approach, as implementation of virtual testbed comes with its line of challenges including high fidelity physics-based system models to capture the fast dynamics, hierarchical modeling approaches, data accessibility, collection, and processing. Therefore, we developed a validated open-source Net Zero Energy Community (NZEC) testbed based on a real community in Florida, USA. Using this testbed, we assessed various case studies including a building-to-grid integration control for demand responsive operation; an occupant thermal preference-aware load scheduler for resilient communities operating in the islanded mode using a chance-constrained scheduler and key resilience indicators; and a new data-driven model to capture occupant behavior in a stochastic manner based on the lighting power consumption.  Further, we developed lower-fidelity data-driven models that require fewer resources to establish and/or run, which is used to assess the optimal renewable resource allocation and load scheduling of resilient communities, through decentralized control architecture. 

In order to augment the finite capabilities of the developed Modelica test beds, we have also explored large scale building energy estimations under various scenarios to support building energy regulation and policy making. Using the large scale building energy estimation methods, we assess the impact of energy efficiency measure selection on the electricity pricing programs and energy impact potential of energy efficiency measures for retrofit applications at the country scale. 

These proposed modeling frameworks have the potential to be further extended for various modeling purposes and use cases, such as community design, dynamic modeling and optimization, resiliency analysis, large scale energy impact analysis and integrated codesign decision making in smart sustainable connected communities and cities. The methods, results and analysis in detail can be found in listed publications. 

The validated and proven virtual community testbed has been shared with the scientific community for big data simulations and modeling. The NZEC and SCC Modelica libraries have been released as opensource, which includes physics-based models, data-driven models, and use case examples for evaluating and optimizing community energy on time scales and fidelity levels. In addition, the training and workshops sessions organized in conference have extended the application of the developed virtual testbeds to the broader research community and the industry. The models have been used by US Department of Energy national laboratories in their research and development projects.

With such diverse explorations, this research led to the creation of a new workforce that is contributing advances to many disciplines beyond the advanced system modeling and simulations using Modelica. 13 full-time graduate students have been trained over the past years on many aspects of the proposed research and have contributed to advances in the areas of data analytics, machine learning, network analysis, optimization theory, stochastic modeling, probability and statistical analysis. For instance, the developed models are realistic, flexible, and scalable so that massive data sets can be generated to train the synthetic data models, which lays the data foundation in big data analytics.  Extensive dissemination through several invited talks, conference presentations and educational seminars at various Universities around the world, have made students and professionals aware of the various concepts and approaches in the modelling and simulation of SCCs.
